conclusion: Determine the velocity v1 of the particles when they reach the collection device.
Particles are emitted from the source S with a charge-to-mass ratio q/m = 2 x 10^6 C/kg and a magnetic field B = 5 x 10^-3 T.
Particles move in a circular path due to the magnetic field and eventually hit the collection device.
The radius r of the circular motion of the particles in the magnetic field is given by r = mv/qB.
Substituting q = 2 x 10^6 m into the equation for the radius, we get r = v/10^4.
Particles are emitted in all directions within the first quadrant.
Distance from the source to the collection device is d = 1.2 m.
Particles will hit the collection device if their path is such that the distance traveled in the circular motion is an integer multiple of the circumference of the circle.
The angle of incidence theta can be determined from the geometry of the problem.
The distance d is the hypotenuse of a right triangle where the vertical distance is the radius r and the horizontal distance is the remaining part of the path.
The angle theta is such that the vertical component of the velocity is v sin theta and the horizontal component is v cos theta.
The vertical distance is r sin theta and the horizontal distance is r cos theta.
The total distance is d = sqrt((r sin theta)^2 + (r cos theta)^2) = r.
The horizontal distance must be an integer multiple of the radius.
The vertical distance must be such that the particle can complete a full circle or part of a circle before hitting the collection device.
Determine the velocity v1 such that the particle hits the collection device after traveling a certain number of full circles.
